description: From Middle English entaillen, from Old French entaillier, entailler (“to notch”, literally “to cut in”); from prefix en- + tailler (“to cut”), from Late Latin taliare, from Latin talea. Compare late Latin feudum talliatum (“a fee entailed, i.e., curtailed or limited”).

verbs.description: entail (third-person singular simple present entails, present participle entailing, simple past and past participle entailed)

examples: This activity will entail careful attention to detail.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To settle or fix inalienably on a person or thing, or on a person and his descendants or a certain line of descendants; -- said especially of an estate; to bestow as a heritage.
examples: Allowing them to entail their estates.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To cut or carve in an ornamental way.

description: From Middle English entaille (“carving”), from Old French entaille (“incision”), from the verb entailler. See above.

entries.meaning: An estate in fee entailed, or limited in descent to a particular class of issue.
The rule by which the descent is fixed.
